testimony.quarrel_subject: Beast escaped onto Nicolas' property, damage
Nicolas wanted to cart a tree witness had felled

testimony.threat_quote: menassant ceulx qu'estoient cause de la mort de sadite femme

testimony.quarrel_subject: Beat Georgette (Nicolas's wife) with stick and drove her away
Accused Nicolas of causing his wife's death
testimony.threat_quote: qu'il estoit cause de la mort de sadite femme, et en quoy on luy avoit faict grand tort, mais que cela ne dormoit encore et n'estoit oblié

harms_alleged.attributed_to: Nicolas Herteman's wife Georgette, then Nicolas

testimony.quarrel_subject: Collecting tithe, took sheaves from their field

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: a fortnight after ox died, cat scratched her, then she languished a year

testimony.quarrel_subject: Witness scolded one of Nicolas's sons for causing injury to witness's son while skating

harms_alleged.target: witness himself (mentioned earlier execution of Georgette)

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after Nicolas came to house and 'fait le hola'

testimony.quarrel_subject: Refused to return 'chaudiere' (cauldron) taken as gage, and called Nicolas's children 'enfants de sorciers'

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 3-4 years after calling children 'enfants de sorciers'

timeline.subject: Georgette femme Nicolas Herteman
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture of Nicolas's wife (already sentenced to death) to obtain accomplice names. She accused her husband Nicolas.

timeline.subject: Georgette femme Nicolas Herteman
timeline.details: Georgette renewed accusation against husband at execution but asked they accept her denials of knowing other witches.

timeline.subject: Nicolas Herteman
timeline.details: PG des Vosges orders secret investigation into Nicolas's repute and conduct.

timeline.subject: Nicolas Herteman
timeline.details: PG des Vosges orders arrest and opening of formal procedure.

timeline.subject: Nicolas Herteman
timeline.details: First interrogation of Nicolas. He denied all charges.

timeline.subject: Nicolas Herteman
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses. No result, complete conflict of evidence.

timeline.subject: Nicolas Herteman
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture: thumbscrews on hands and feet, racked three times. Continued to deny all accusations.

timeline.subject: Nicolas Herteman
timeline.details: PG proposes he be 'renvoyé jusques à rappel' (released subject to recall).

timeline.subject: Nicolas Herteman
timeline.details: Prévôt de Bruyères reports Nicolas has been released, not liable for costs, exhorted to live peacefully with neighbours.

accomplices_named.name: Nicolas Herteman
accomplices_named.context: Named by his wife Georgette under torture and at execution as the one who seduced her to sabbat 9 years before

accomplices_named.name: Monzouille
accomplices_named.context: Named by Georgette as seen at sabbat

accomplices_named.name: wife of Mongeon Voiry
accomplices_named.context: Named by Georgette as seen at sabbat

accomplices_named.name: Tiriot le Duc
accomplices_named.context: Named by Georgette as assisting Devil in cell (appeared as great rat with claws)

prior_accusations.context: Wife accused Nicolas under torture of seducing her to sabbat 9 years before, renewed at execution

notable_quotes.speaker: Georgette femme Nicolas Herteman
notable_quotes.french: Allegant que sa mere l'avoit fort tansé, mais qu'en haine de ce il l'auroit ceste fois, et que l'aiant beaucoup de fois tarabusté, il gaigna tant sur elle, qu'elle le promit de croire en luy.
notable_quotes.english: Alleging that her mother had scolded her severely, but that in hatred of this he would have her this time, and that having pestered her many times, he gained so much over her that she promised to believe in him.
notable_quotes.context: Georgette describing her seduction by the Devil at age 12 while guarding sheep

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Herteman
notable_quotes.french: plusieurs affronts qu'on luy faisoit, en luy jectant des pierres contre ses portes et l'appellans sorcier
notable_quotes.english: several affronts that were done to him, throwing stones against his doors and calling him sorcerer
notable_quotes.context: Nicolas complaining to Claudon Aucel at the mill about how he was being treated

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Herteman
notable_quotes.context: How Nicolas said he was seen by others

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengel le Duc
notable_quotes.french: l'en avoit tousiours depuis voulu mal et porté mauvais visage, menassant ceulx qu'estoient cause de la mort de sadite femme
notable_quotes.english: had always since wished him ill and shown bad face, threatening those who were cause of the death of his said wife
notable_quotes.context: Describing Nicolas's attitude after witness deposed against Georgette

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas and Georgette Herteman
notable_quotes.context: Threat to Thiriot le Duc after he took tithe sheaves from their field

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Mongeot
notable_quotes.french: qu'il estoit cause de la mort de sadite femme, et en quoy on luy avoit faict grand tort, mais que cela ne dormoit encore et n'estoit oblié
notable_quotes.english: that he was cause of the death of his said wife, and in which they had done him great wrong, but that this was not yet sleeping and was not forgotten
notable_quotes.context: Nicolas's reproach to witness after Georgette's execution

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Herteman
notable_quotes.french: quelquefois en paix, et par autre avec quelque fascherie, comme ordinairement arrive, et qu'il ne vit oncques aucun mal en elle, sinon qu'elle avoit un mauvais courage
notable_quotes.english: sometimes in peace, and at other times with some vexation, as ordinarily happens, and that he never saw any evil in her, except that she had a bad temper
notable_quotes.context: Nicolas describing his marriage to Georgette during interrogation

relationships.evidence_text: His wife executed for witchcraft November 1615
daughter Fleurate came to ask for cauldron
one of Nicolas' sons involved in skating incident
Nicolas' father had told them off for quarrelling, meix belonging to Hertemans
her brother-in-law Humbert Gagnel, paistre du troupeau des porcs, with whom she lived
his son Mengeon had been ill; finally died
his daughter found a cat there; scratched her face, fell ill, languished a year and died
serious illness afflicting his wife; her legs were so weak she could not stand
caused one of his own sons to fall and injure his eye badly
bewitching his wife, taken to Ambrosian Father at Bruyères
daughter Fleurate came to ask for cauldron back
his aunt, wife of an uncle, already executed

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over property boundaries (animals escaping onto Nicolas's land, quarrel over felled tree). Cauldron taken as gage after Georgette's execution suggests debt/property seizure. Nicolas was subject to tithe collection.

harms_catalog.harm_description: Became ill and languished for 5 months before dying
Legs all bitten or torn after being near meix where accused was
Shoulder hurt after Nicolas touched it
Fell ill and died while drinking near meix belonging to Hertemans
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Nicolas wanted to cart a tree witness had felled

harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell off ladder and hurt leg badly, fell wrong way in unnatural fashion, at first thought dead
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Had deposed against Nicolas's wife, Nicolas bore ill-will and threatened

harms_catalog.harm_description: Mysteriously drowned in shallow stream which only came up to man's knees
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Witness beat Georgette with stick, caused her arrest and execution

harms_catalog.harm_description: Bewitched, became ill (found 'tortillons de plumes' in bed), recovered after Ambrosian Father's remedy, then became ill again worse than before
harms_catalog.attributed_to: Georgette first, then Nicolas Herteman after reproach
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Nicolas reproached witness for causing Georgette's death

harms_catalog.harm_description: Became ill and died as if rabid
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Thiriot took tithe sheaves from their field despite resistance

harms_catalog.harm_description: Cat scratched her face while she drove it from stable, fell ill within fortnight, languished a year then died
Serious illness (caused by Georgette according to earlier trial)
Legs so weak she could not stand
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Witness scolded Nicolas's son for causing injury to witness's son skating, Nicolas came to house and frightened wife

harms_catalog.harm_description: Eye badly injured when caused to fall while skating on ice
Became sick and still in poor state
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refused to return cauldron to Fleurate

Nicolas claimed to be looking for lost hatchet by ford at 1 a.m.
Found in bed of Nicolas Mongeot's wife, judged by Ambrosian Father to be magical
Method witches used to bring down hail on crops according to Georgette's confession
Torture instrument used on Georgette and Nicolas
Torture instrument used on Georgette and Nicolas (three times)
Jean Voiry beat Georgette with a stick to drive her away
Thrown against Nicolas's doors by people calling him sorcerer
Tithe collection dispute with Thiriot le Duc
Mengel le Duc fell from ladder and hurt leg

weather_events: hail on wheat and other crops brought down by witches with baguettes (18 months before November 1615)
windy with rain (night witness 3 encountered Nicolas at ford)
economic_hardship_indicators: tithe collection (Thiriot le Duc found virtually nothing left in Herteman field)
property taken as gage for debt

prior_legal_disputes.description: Nicolas was called 'sorcier' publicly, people threw stones at his doors. He considered seeking redress but did not.
Nicolas Napuel called Nicolas's children 'enfants de sorciers'. They considered proceeding against him but never did.

legal_context.redress_outcome: Claudon Aucel advised him he could seek redress if innocent, but Nicolas never did so

hearsay_chains.content: Georgette suspected of bewitching Bernard Viry due to hatred

emotional_state_notes: Under pressure during interrogation but continued denials
Complained about being called sorcerer and having stones thrown at doors
Considered fleeing to let rumors die down

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: His meaning at mill was that IF he were a witch he would flee, not admission
Insisted he really was looking for hatchet by ford

extraction_metadata.notes: This is an exceptionally significant case: Nicolas Herteman was accused by his executed wife Georgette under torture and at execution, yet he maintained his innocence throughout interrogation and even under severe torture (thumbscrews and rack three times). He was ultimately released 'jusques à rappel' (subject to recall) and not liable for costs. This represents one of the rare non-death outcomes in the Lorraine trials. The case demonstrates: (1) extreme suspicion due to family connection to executed witches (wife and aunt); (2) long-standing reputation (20+ years); (3) multiple witnesses alleging maleficia following quarrels; (4) community persecution (stones thrown, called sorcier publicly); (5) Nicolas's awareness of legal options but failure to seek redress; (6) resistance under torture leading to release. The document contains rich detail about material culture (feather bundles as evidence), spatial geography (meix properties, ford, mill), social relationships, and the psychology of accusation within families. Georgette's confession under torture provides detailed sabbat narrative and seduction account from age 12.
